summary.seg: The manuscript is a collection of ethical treatises by the philosopher Aristotle or attributed to him. MS Ii.5.44 was copied for the monastery of S. Salvatore in Lingua Phari (near modern-day Messina), an important centre of Italo-Greek monasticism in Sicily, and was completed on 16th June 1279. The copyist presents himself in the colophon as Nikolaos ἀναγνώστης τῶν ὡρῶν. This means "reader of the hours", so he may have been a novice of the monastery, appointed as "lector at the Hours". A more likely explanation, however, is that it describes his own origins as a member of the Greek clergy of the city of Ora in Apulia.

Nikolaos seems also to have copied
Vatican City, Bibliotheca Apostolica Vaticana, Vaticanus gr. 1342 , which is not signed but considered the twin of this manuscript, given the identical contents. Together, they constitute the recensio Messanensis of Aristotle's ethical treatises.

The copyist Nikolas seems to have copied the text of the eighth book of Ethica Nicomachea up to the third line of f. 86r and, realizing that there was a lacuna, has left a line and a half empty (ll. 3-4). The lacuna was filled in the late 15th century with an insertion in the eleventh quire of a binion, probably copied by Baldassar Migliavacca. This scribe, besides having left notes in the margins on the whole manuscript, has also erased the text of the first three lines of f. 86r to make his intervention match with the text copied by Nikolaos.
The manuscript is signed C or Cc in the editions.

physDesc.p: Manuscript core dated 1279 with 15th century inserted quire (ff. 85ar-85dv).

seg.note: A strip of 20 x 200 mm has been cut off from f. 1 and replaced with modern parchment.

foliation.p: Modern foliation in pencil in Arabic numerals in the top right-hand corner, recto: the first three endleaves are numbered from 2 to 4; the parchment leaves were numbered from 1 to 147 (the 1858 catalogue refers to this numbering), then Henry Bradshaw struck out the numbers from 86 onwards, replacing them with the sequence 85a-d for the inserted quire, and 86-143 for the second part of the original manuscript.

condition.p: In fair condition, with occasional spots and wormholes.

binding.p: 20th-century couched-laminated board binding, sheepskin with blind embossing reused from previous boards (probably 16th or 17th century). Leather strips with tooled titles from previous bindings are glued to the front pastedown . Title (Aristoteles Ethica &c.) and shelfmark tooled in gold on spine. On the upper right corner of left pastedown there is an illegible note in black ink (probably the name of the binder) and a date in pencil: 1959.

history.provenance:
The manuscript probably belonged to the library of Baldassar Migliavacca Meliavacca, Baltasar
, who seems to be responsible for the restoration of quire 11*.

The manuscript certainly later entered into the collection of
John Moore (1646-1714), bishop of Ely Moore, John, 1646-1714 : number 981 (classmark noted on front pastedown) in the handwritten supplementary list of Moore's manuscripts, now CUL Oo.7.50.2, compiled by Thomas Tanner (1674-1735) after the publication of Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ (1697).
history.acquisition:
Presented to the University Library in 1715 by
George I George I, King of Great Britain, 1660-1727 . The royal bookplate engraved by John Pine (1690-1756) in 1736 remains on front pastedown.

recordHist.source: Description (2019) draws on A catalogue of the Manuscripts preserved in the Library of the University of Cambridge, vol. 3 (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1858), pp. 495-496 and J. Wiesner's record in P. Moraux, Aristoteles Graecus (Berlin-New York: Walter De Gruyter, 1976), pp. 104-107.

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

msContents.textLang: Greek with few notes in Latin

msItem.author: Aristotle
msItem.title: Magna Moralia
msItem.rubric: f. 1r Ἀριστοτέλους ἠθικῶν Νικομαχείων μεγάλων α
msItem.incipit: f. 1r Ἐπειδὴ προαιρούμεθα λέγειν ὑπὲρ ἠθικῶν, πρῶτον ἂν εἴη σκεπτέον τίνος ἐστὶ μέρος τὸ ἦθος
msItem.explicit: f. 30v ὥστε σκεπτέον ἂν εἴη τὸ πῶς δεῖ χρῆσθαι φίλω ἐν τῆ ἐν ἴσοις φίλοις φιλία

msItem.author: Aristotle
msItem.title: Nicomachean Ethics
Ethica Nicomachea
msItem.incipit: f. 30v Πᾶσα τέχνη καὶ πᾶσα μέθοδος, ὁμοίως δὲ πρᾶξίς τε καὶ προαίρεσις, ἀγαθοῦ τινὸς ἐφίεσθαι δοκεῖ
msItem.explicit: f. 102v καὶ πῶς ἑκάστη ταχθεῖσα, καὶ τίσι νόμοις καὶ ἔθεσι χρωμένη. λέγωμεν οὖν ἀρξάμενοι

msItem.author: Aristotle
msItem.title: Eudemian Ethics
Ethica Eudemia
msItem.incipit: f. 102v Ὁ μὲν ἐν Δήλω παρὰ τῶ θῶ τὴν αὐτοῦ γνώμην ἀποφηνάμενος συνέγραψεν ἐπὶ τὸ προπύλαιον τοῦ Λητώου
msItem.explicit: f. 134v τις μὲν οὖν ὅρος τῆς καλοκαγαθίας, καὶ τίς ὁ σκοπὸς τῶν ἁπλῶς ἀγαθῶν, ἔστω εἰρημένον

msItem.author: pseudo-Aristotle
msItem.title: Economics (defective at the end)
Oeconomica
msItem.incipit: f. 134v Ἡ οἰκονομικὴ καὶ πολιτικὴ διαφέρει οὐ μόνον τοσοῦτον ὅσον οἰκία καὶ πόλις
msItem.explicit: f. 143v εὐωδέστερα δοῦναι· εἶτα ἱμάτια μὲν λευκά, στεφάνους δὲ λευκίνους περιετίθει

msItem.title: Colophon
msItem.colophon: ἐγράφη τὸ παρὸν βιβλίον τῆς ἠθικῆς τοῦ Ἀριστοτέλους διὰ χειρὸς Νικολάου εὐτελοῦς ἀναγνώστου τῶν ὡρῶν, αἰτήσει τοῦ θεοτιμήτου μοναχοῦ κυρίου Ἰακὼβ σκευοφύλακος μάνδρας ἀκρωτηρίου μηνὶ Ἰουνίου ιϛ, ἰνδικτιώνος ζ, ἔτει ϛψπζ. οἱ ἀναγινώσκοντες εὔχεσθε ὑπὲρ αὐτῶν

support.material: ff. 1r-143v parchment, medium thickness, good quality, arranged flesh-to-flesh and hair-to-hair with flesh outermost (FHHF).

collation.p: The manuscript consisted originally of 18 quaternions. The last leaf of quire 18 was cancelled in all likelihood at the time of the making of the volume, so the first, loose leaf (f. 137) was then attached to quire 17. The outermost folios of each quire are reinforced by a strip of paper.

list.item: Quires 1-118 ff. 1r-88v (the second bifolia of quires 4, 6, 8, 9, 10 have been cut out and substituted in their second half by the copyist; quire 11*, ff. 85ar-dv, is inserted after the fifth bifolium of quire 11, f. 85)

collation.signatures: Original quire signatures in brown ink, in Greek numerals, survive on the first folio, recto side, of quires 13-17, consistent with the original collation: ιγ (f. 97r) - ιη (f. 137r).

signatures.p: Leaf signatures in Latin letters for quires from a to s, and Arabic numerals for bifolios in pencil in the lower right-hand corner of the rectos, by Henry Bradshaw (1831-1886), along with a note on the collation on the rear pastedown.

supportDesc.condition: The upper margin of f. 1 was cut out, probably because a previous ownership note, and repaired with a parchment strip. The edges are blackened and the folios yellowed. There are dirt deposits on ff. 9v-10r, 11v-12r; a rectangular strip of parchment (15 x 5 mm) is glued to f. 25r. Several holes are present, both the natural ones of the parchment and due to worms.

layoutDesc.layout:
ff. 1r-143v: written space 200 135
Main text always 26-27 lines per page. Pricked in the outer margins. Ruled in brown-redish ink, type Leroy 00D1 .

handNote.p: Hand A: The manuscript is written by Nikolaos (RGK I 327), as stated in the colophon, in an informal mixed minuscule script, below top line, upright in brown ink for the text and in red ink for titles. His minuscule follows the models of the typical scriptures of the Terra d'Otranto.

The circular-shape letters and and elongated alphas are filled in red. There is a marked variation in letter size. Syllabic abbreviations and superscription are commonly used. Breathings are round and mute iota is absent. Nikolaos' informal hand is characterized by a fast execution with moderately sinuous and curved shapes. The tau is often high, with the horizontal stroke always curved and often elongated to the base, which sometimes leads to a hook shape (e.g. f. 30v lines 14 and 26).
Punctuation used includes the middle and upper point, middle and lower comma (rarely), and full stop.
For further details on Nikolaos' script, see Jacob Nicolas d'Oria Un copiste de Pouille au Saint-Sauveur de Messine (1985), pp. 139-143.

Hand B: the hand who wrote the inserted quire (ff. 85a-d) also wrote marginal notes throughout the manuscript and the first four lines of f. 86r, and the book numbers of Nicomachean Ethics in Greek numerals on upper corner, recto side, from f. 31r.

decoDesc.decoNote: Thick red-ink book initials along with palmettes in red ink on ff. 1r, 15v, 30v, 38r, 44r, 52v, 60v, 69r, 74v, 84r, 87v, 94v, 102v, 107r, 115v, 121r, 121v, 131v, 134v, 136v, 143v.
The inner spaces of some letters, especially those with a circular shape, and elongated alphas are filled in red.

additions.p: Annotations in Latin made throughout the manuscript, nearly lost in trimming if on lower margin (e.g. f. 14r).
Some maniculae added by Hand B: ff. 99v, 100v
A portion of a red cotton thread was pinned to f. 107.
f. 127r: a note in pencil with correspondence to the Bekker edition: 1241a
Annotations in pencil by Henry Bradshaw on ff. 86r, 143v and left pastedown.

history.origin: The manuscript was copied in Messina on 16th June a.m. 6787 = AD 1279, by Nikolaos, "lector of the Hours", on request of the monk Iakobos, skeuophylax of the abbey of S. Salvatore in Lingua Phari.

msContents.textLang: Greek with few notes in Latin

msItem.author: Aristotle
msItem.title: Nicomachean Ethics 8, 4-14
msItem.incipit: f. 85ar -πευόμενος ὑπὸ τοῦ ἐραστοῦ· ληγούσης δὲ τῆς ὥρας ἐνίοτε καὶ ἡ φιλία λήγει τῶ μὲν γὰρ οὐκ ἔστιν ἡδεῖα ἡ ὄψις (1157a)
msItem.explicit: f. 85dv ἀφορίσειε δ’ ἄν τις, τήν τε συγγενικὴν, καὶ τὴν ἑταιρικήν αἱ δὲ πολιτικαὶ, καὶ φυλετικαὶ καὶ συμπλοϊκαί, καὶ (1161b)
msItem.note: the addition continues on f. 86r line 1-4

support.material: ff. 85ar-85dv parchment, medium thickness, good quality, arranged flesh-to-flesh and hair-to-hair with flesh outermost (FHHF).

collation.p: One binion (11*) is inserted after the fifth bifolio of quire 11, f. 85

signatures.p: Leaf signatures in Latin letters ll (quire 11 marked as l) and Arabic numerals for bifolios in pencil in the lower right-hand corner of the rectos, by Henry Bradshaw (1831-1886).

layoutDesc.layout:
ff. 85ar-85dv: written space 197 140
26 lines per page. Pricked in the lower margins. Ruled in pencil, only bounding lines traced.

handNote.p:
Hand B: according to D. Harlfinger, the quire was probably written by the scribe and scholar Andronicus Callistus Andronicus Callistus, -1478 (RGK I 18) in a minuscule script. More recently (see Orlandi, Baldassar Migliavacca lettore e possessore di codici greci (2014), pp. 173-175), the restoration was attributed to Baltasar Meliavacca Meliavacca, Baltasar
, active as commentator and book collector in the last quarter of the 15th century in Milan, and student of Callistus, from whom he acquired part of the library, such as Cambridge, University Library, MS Nn.3.18 . The handwriting of the Italian collector imitates that of the master and also tries to reproduce some characteristics of the hand of Nikolaos.

Syllabic abbreviations and superscript letter endings usually appear only at the end of lines and rarely elsewhere (e.g. common abbreviation of μεν or ἐστίν). Breathings are curved and joined to accents; circumflex accent is hat-like; almost vertical acutes and graves. Isolated trema is sometimes traced over iota and ypsilon; mute iota is present but not constantly used.

history.origin: The manuscript was copied in all likelihood in the 15th century, probably before 1475, to fill the lacuna of the manuscript core.
